title: Cat. 51  Blue Vase on a Venetian Armchair, 1943
publication_title: Matisse Paintings, Works on Paper, Sculpture, and Textiles at the Art Institute of Chicago
content:
<section class="osci-tk-epub-section tombstone" id="tombstone">Blue Vase on a Venetian Armchair  
Vence, 1943  
Colored pencils on ivory wove paper; 52.5 × 40.5 cm (20 3/4 × 16 in.)  
Signed: HM (lower left, in graphite)  
The Art Institute of Chicago, gift of Dorothy Braude Edinburg to the Harry B. and Bessie K. Braude Memorial Collection, 2013.977

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section curatorial_entry" id="curatorial_entry">In 1942, Henri Matisse made the fortuitous discovery of a Venetian armchair (fig. 51.1) in an antique shop. As he wrote to the Surrealist poet Louis Aragon in April 1942, “I finally found the object I have been seeking for more than a year. It is a baroque Venetian chair varnished with silver tints. Like an enamel . . . When I found it in an antique shop I was bowled over. It is splendid, I am possessed by it.” As pictured in the artist’s studio (see fig. 51.2), this stunning object had metallic scallop-shells for the seat and back, and green eel-like armrests with monstrous heads. It appears in many of his works, including Dancer and Rocaille Armchair on a Black Background (1942; fig. 51.3) and Rocaille Armchair (1946; fig. 51.4). While the chair is often depicted as a solid golden block of color with green or blue arms in his paintings, for his fluid 1943 colored-pencil drawing Blue Vase on a Venetian Armchair he used sweeping pencil strokes to capture its elaborate detail and slithering, animalistic armrests. The flattened form frames the blue vase, with its flowing green leaves and yellow flowers, augmenting the organic form and decorative elements of the chair.

Around this time, Matisse began a series of line drawings, one hundred and fifty-eight of which were published in 1943 under the collective title Themes and Variations and divided into seventeen sequences according to subject. This colored-pencil study of a vase of flowers on an armchair is perhaps a direct descendent of the series. The drawing shares with the suite an economy of line and an emphasis on flat shapes. Blue Vase on a Venetian Armchair, however, differs from the deceptively simple drawings of Themes and Variations in the greater intensity of the parallel lines in the chair arms and the bouquet’s blooms and leaves. It is further distinguished from drawings in the series by the composition’s ornamental nature and the exaggeration of the linear components, which are more cursive and stylized.  
Brandon Ruud and Marin Sarvé-Tarr

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section technical_report" id="technical_report">Henri Matisse drew the composition directly in colored pencils, with no preliminary marks, on ivory wove paper. He drew with his pencils held at an angle, using the side of the tip to lay in broad, colored strokes. The colored pencils recorded the fine screen pattern on the paper surface, leaving broken, textured lines (see fig. 51.5). Matisse used greater pressure to draw the yellow flowers, which yielded denser lines; microscope examination at 80× shows a buildup of waxy binder along the yellow pencil strokes (see fig. 51.6). Where two dense strokes appear adjacent to one another they create the illusion of a white line drawn between them. This is only the white of the paper.

There are pinholes at all corners and at the center of the right and left edges, likely from pinning the paper to a support while drawing. There is a faint black residue on the verso in the region of the pencil lines, indicating that some black material was picked up from the surface of Matisse’s drawing board by the pressure of his pencils. The sheet has not been cut down.

Signed: HM (lower left, in graphite) (fig. 51.7).

Colored pencils.

The support is moderately thick, moderately textured, ivory wove paper. The sheet has a very fine yet pronounced screen pattern. The top and bottom have a deckle edge. The right and left have an imitation deckle edge, indicating that the paper is moldmade. There is a watermark in the upper left corner: Arches (1 × 3 cm) (fig. 51.8).

52.5 × 40.5 cm (20 3/4 × 16 in.).

Examination indicates that the work has not undergone conservation treatment.

The edges exhibit tight cockling. There are brown stains near each corner on the verso (fig. 51.9), likely from earlier adhesive.

There is minor black residue on the verso deposited along some drawn lines, suggesting the pressure from the pencils caused material to offset from the support used during drawing.  
Kristi Dahm

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section provenance" id="provenance">Probably Jacques Dubourg (1897–1981), Galerie Jacques Dubourg, Paris, by June 1962.

Unidentified owner.

Sold, Sotheby’s London, lot 420, to Dorothy Braude Edinburg (c. 1921–Jan. 5, 2015), Brookline, MA, June 25, 1986–June 19, 2013.

Given to the Art Institute of Chicago, June 19, 2013.

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section exhibitions" id="exhibitions">Paris, Galerie Jacques Dubourg, Henri Matisse: Aquarelles, dessins, June 1962, cat. 34 (ill.), as Vase bleu sur un fauteuil vénitien, 1943.

Art Institute of Chicago, Drawings in Dialogue: Old Master through Modern; The Harry B. and Bessie K. Braude Memorial Collection, June 3–July 30, 2006, cat. 149 (ill.), as Blue Vase on a Venetian Armchair, 1943.

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section references" id="references">Jacques Dubourg, Henri Matisse: Aquarelles, dessins, exh. cat. (Galerie Jacques Dubourg, 1962), cat. 34 (ill.), as Vase bleu sur un fauteuil vénitien, 1943.

Sotheby’s, London, Impressionist and Modern Drawings and Watercolours, sale cat. (Sotheby’s, June 25, 1986), p. 119, lot 420 (ill.), as Vase bleu sur un fauteuil venitien [sic], Nice, 1943.

Brandon Ruud, “Catalogue: Modernism: Henri Matisse: 149,” in Drawings in Dialogue: Old Master through Modern; The Harry B. and Bessie K. Braude Memorial Collection, exh. cat., ed. Suzanne Folds McCullagh (Art Institute of Chicago/Yale University Press, 2006), p. 202, cat. 149 (ill.), as Blue Vase on a Venetian Armchair, 1943.

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section other_documentation" id="other_documentation">The media and their application, as well as the condition of the artwork, were assessed through visual examination using normal, transmitted, and raking light; microscope magnification (80–300×); and ultraviolet-light examination (254 and 365 nm). The beta radiograph was recorded using a Konica Minolta Regius Σ imaging plate (FP-1S) and a Konica Minolta Direct Digitizer Regius ΣII computed radiography scanner with ImagePilot software set on low–image processing intensity.

</section><section epub:type="footnotes" id="footnotes">Henri Matisse to Louis Aragon, Apr. 1942, as translated in Gérard Durozoi, Matisse (Bracken, 1989), p. 132.

For example, the theme of series B is a half-length portrait of a model seated in an armchair. Most of the works are devoted to figures, but there are also several still-life motifs, such as series G (an array of Matisse’s favorite props, including the blue vase), series H (a single vase with ivy), and series M (fruit and flowers). Themes and Variations includes sheets drawn in various media, including crayon, pen and ink, and pencil. Furthermore, Matisse made subtle changes to the compositions of each drawing in a sequence, a process he described as “a cinematography of the sentiments of an artist.” Henri Matisse, quoted in Francis Carco, “Conversation avec Matisse,” in L’ami des peintres (Gallimard, 1953), as translated in “Interview with Francis Carco, 1941,” in Jack Flam, Matisse on Art, rev. ed. (University of California Press, 1995), p. 135. For more the Themes and Variations series, see Staatsgalerie Stuttgart, Henri Matisse: Zeichnungen und Gouaches Decoupées (Hatje Cantz, 1993), pp. 139–214; Musée National d’Art Occidental, Henri Matisse: Processus/Variation (Musée National d’Art Occidental, 2004), pp. 212–17; and Samantha Rippner, “Themes and Variations,” in Matisse: In Search of True Painting, exh. cat., ed. Dorthe Aagesen and Rebecca Rabinow (Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York, 2012), pp. 164–69.

This entry is partially adapted from Brandon Rudd’s text on the work in Drawings in Dialogue: Old Master through Modern; The Harry B. and Bessie K. Braude Memorial Collection, exh. cat., ed. Suzanne Fold McCullagh (Art Institute of Chicago/Yale University Press, 2006), p. 202; with additional text by Marin Sarvé-Tarr.

Descriptions of paper thickness and texture follow the standard set forth in Elizabeth Lunning and Roy Perkinson, The Print Council of America Paper Sample Book: A Practical Guide to the Description of Paper (Print Council of America/Sun Hill, 1996).

This Arches watermark appears in three other Matisse drawings in the Art Institute of Chicago’s collection: Matisse’s Dining Room—1941 (1941; cat. 50), Head of a Woman (1942; cat. 49), and Head (1947; cat. 57). The mark designates a particular ivory, moldmade drawing paper. “Matisse often used this paper for his drawings. It also appears frequently in the smaller cut-outs of the late 1940s and, occasionally, in large cut-outs of the 1950s.” Antoinette King, “Technical Appendix,” in Jack Cowart, Henri Matisse: Paper Cut-Outs, with Jack D. Flam, Dominique Fourcade, John Hallmark Neff, John Haletsky, and Antoinette King, exh. cat. (Saint Louis Art Museum, 1977), p. 272.

Jacques Dubourg, Henri Matisse: Aquarelles, dessins, exh. cat. (Galerie Jacques Dubourg, 1962), cat. 34 (ill.).

Sotheby’s, London, Impressionist and Modern Drawings and Watercolours, sale cat. (Sotheby’s, June 25, 1986), p. 119, lot 420 (ill.) and Business Approved by the Board of Trustees, June 19, 2013, n.pag; photocopies in curatorial object file, Department of Prints and Drawings, Art Institute of Chicago

Board of Trustees meeting minutes, redacted version, June 19, 2013, pp. 2, 5; photocopy in curatorial object file, Department of Prints and Drawings, Art Institute of Chicago.

</section><section id="figures">Cat. 51 Blue Vase on a Venetian Armchair, 1943.

fig. 51.1 Venetian armchair that belonged to Henri Matisse. Musée Matisse, Nice.

fig. 51.3 Henri Matisse (French, 1869–1954). Dancer and Rocaille Armchair on a Black Background, 1942. Oil on canvas; 64.8 × 50.8 cm (25 1/2 × 20 in.). Private collection.

fig. 51.4 Henri Matisse (French, 1869–1954). Rocaille Armchair, 1946. Oil on canvas; 92 x 73 cm (36 1/4 × 28 3/ in.). Musée Matisse, Nice.

fig. 51.2 Cushioned armchair and vase of flowers on a Venetian armchair in Henri Matisse’s studio. Photograph by Hélène Adant. Bibliothèque Kandinsky, Musee National d’Art Moderne, Centre Georges Pompidou, Paris.

fig. 51.5 Photomicrograph of the chair arm in Matisse’s Blue Vase on a Venetian Armchair (1943) showing how the colored pencils recorded the fine screen pattern on the paper surface. The Art Institute of Chicago, 2013.977.

fig. 51.6 Detail of Matisse’s Blue Vase on a Venetian Armchair (1943) showing that the artist used greater pressure to draw the yellow flowers at upper left, yielding denser, waxy lines. The Art Institute of Chicago, 2013.977.

fig. 51.7 Detail of Matisse’s Blue Vase on a Venetian Armchair (1943) showing the signature. The Art Institute of Chicago, 2013.977.

fig. 51.8 Beta radiograph showing the watermark near the upper left corner of Matisse’s Blue Vase on a Venetian Armchair (1943). The Art Institute of Chicago, 2013.977.

fig. 51.9 Verso of Matisse’s Blue Vase on a Venetian Armchair (1943). The Art Institute of Chicago, 2013.977.

</section>
